channel.title: Defense
channel.description: News, Analysis and Opinion from POLITICO

item.title: A Vance ally rises at the Pentagon — with Trump's blessing
item.description: Dan Driscoll’s visit to Ukraine this week underscored his new prominence in the administration.

media:content.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office via AP
media:content.media:title: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy shakes hands with U.S. Army Secretary Dan Driscoll in Kyiv, Ukraine on Nov. 20, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch, Sophia Cai and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch, Sophia Cai and Paul McLeary

item.title: Top Army officials visit Kyiv on peace and tech sharing mission
item.description: It's the highest-level visit by the Trump administration to the war-torn country since Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent traveled to Kyiv in February.

media:content.media:title: Army Secretary Dan Driscoll (above) and chief of staff Gen. Randy George have used Ukrainian battlefield innovations as an example the U.S. defense industry and Pentagon should emulate in weapons development.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch

item.title: Trump says he will sell F-35s to Saudi Arabia
item.description: The president's comments, which could antagonize Israel, come a day before he welcomes Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to the White House.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump arrives with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for a group photo with Gulf Cooperation Council leaders during the GCC Summit in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on May 14, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Eli Stokols, Paul McLeary, Jack Detsch and Felicia Schwartz
item.dc:contributor: By Eli Stokols, Paul McLeary, Jack Detsch and Felicia Schwartz

item.title: Republicans turn on Trump’s defense policy chief
item.description: Administration allies say they are fed up with the Defense Department’s third-most senior leader and his foreign policy surprises.

media:content.media:title: Elbridge Colby, nominee to be undersecretary of Defense for policy, arrives for a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee at the U.S. Capitol in Washington on March 4, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould, Connor O'Brien and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould, Connor O'Brien and Paul McLeary

item.title: Hegseth, in tone shift, talks nice to defense industry
item.description: The Pentagon chief offered a rare message of unity in a Friday speech to executives.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth salutes as he and South Korean Defense Minister Ahn Gyu-back inspect a guard of honor in Seoul, South Korea, on Nov. 4.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary, Jack Detsch and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary, Jack Detsch and Joe Gould

item.title: Trump nominates Isaacman to run NASA — again
item.description: The unprecedented move follows a high-profile fight over who will run the space agency.

media:content.media:title: Jared Isaacman, U.S. President Donald Trump's nominee to be NASA administrator, testifies during a Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee confirmation hearing in the Russell Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill on April 9, 2025, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Audrey Decker
item.dc:contributor: By Audrey Decker

item.title: Canada, in push away from US, aims to invest billions in defense
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s budget, released Tuesday, calls for a new industrial strategy and a multibillion-dollar project to bolster Ottawa’s defense spending.

media:content.media:title: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is flanked by Chief of the Defence Staff Gen. Carignan, left, and Minister of National Defence, David McGuinty, as they attend a tour of the Fort York Armoury in Toronto on June 9, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: Former Vice President Dick Cheney dies at 84
item.description: His career was about the accumulation of power — and the use of it.

media:content.media:title: Vice President Dick Cheney in 2007.

item.dc:creator: By David Cohen
item.dc:contributor: By David Cohen

item.title: A confidential manifesto lays out Isaacman's sweeping new vision for NASA
item.description: The former, and possibly future, nominee for the space agency said he did not intend for the document’s public release.

media:content.media:title: Jared Isaacman, former nominee for NASA Administrator, testifies during a Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee confirmation hearing on April 09, 2025, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Audrey Decker
item.dc:contributor: By Audrey Decker

item.title: Hegseth seeks a reboot of US-China military hotlines
item.description: Defense secretary praises U.S.-China relations but says better communications needed to “deconflict and deescalate any problems that arise.”

media:content.media:title: U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, center, applauds during the ASEAN Defense Ministers' Meeting - Plus in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Saturday, Nov. 1, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Phelim Kine
item.dc:contributor: By Phelim Kine

item.title: Resuming nuclear testing is not as easy as you think
item.description: The country faces a slew of safety, ethical and logistical challenges to restart long-halted nuclear tests. It could still happen.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping look at each other after their summit meeting in Busan, South Korea, on Oct. 30, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Joe Gould

item.title: DOD can’t say who it killed in military strikes against drug smugglers
item.description: Lawmakers left frustrated after a classified briefing with department officials.

media:content.media:title: “[The department officials] said that they do not need to positively identify individuals on these vessels to do the strikes, they just need to prove a connection to a designated terrorist organization or affiliate,” said Rep. Sara Jacobs.

item.dc:creator: By Leo Shane III
item.dc:contributor: By Leo Shane III

item.title: Trump’s National Guard DC deployment extended into 2026
item.description: The troops have been patrolling high-profile areas and collecting trash.

media:content.media:title: National Guard members are seen alongside tourists on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., Aug. 14, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: Trump will arm South Korea with a nuclear submarine
item.description: South Korea’s nuclear submarine development plans reflect Seoul’s concerns about potential Chinese and North Korean aggression.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump said the submarine will be built at Hanwha Philly Shipyard (above), a commercial yard purchased by a South Korean company in 2024.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Phelim Kine
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Phelim Kine

item.title: Hegseth to unveil arms sale overhaul
item.description: The Defense secretary will announce changes to the Pentagon’s weapons purchases at an unusual gathering of defense industry executives.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gives a thumbs-up to soldiers after delivering a speech at the Navy's Yokosuka base in Japan on Oct. 28, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould and Paul McLeary

item.title: Takaichi’s tightrope: Flatter Trump, don’t feed him
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi faces an early leadership test in managing Trump’s concerns about Japanese investment and defense spending

media:content.media:title: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi attends the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Oct. 26, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Phelim Kine and Sophia Cai
item.dc:contributor: By Phelim Kine and Sophia Cai

item.title: Hegseth’s first dismissal with a chosen successor
item.description: The Defense secretary’s decision to place his senior military aide in a top Army post represents a new front in his efforts to overhaul the Pentagon.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth speaks at an event to mark the upcoming Marine Corps' 250th anniversary on Oct 18, 2025, in Camp Pendleton, California.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: DOD accepts anonymous $130M donation to partially cover troop pay
item.description: White House and military officials will not say who the donor is or whether the gift has been properly vetted.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump said an anonymous donor have given $130 million to help cover the costs of military pay.

item.dc:creator: By Leo Shane III, Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Leo Shane III, Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch

item.title: Trump orders US carrier strike group to Caribbean
item.description: The move is a major escalation of warships in the region.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump has ordered the aircraft carrier USS Gerald R. Ford to the Caribbean in a major escalation in the region.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: Abandoned NASA nominee may find new life
item.description: It’s a surprising turn in Washington, where nominees rarely get this kind of second chance.

media:content.media:title: Jared Isaacman, President Donald Trump's nominee to be NASA chief, testifies during a Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee confirmation hearing on April 9, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Chris Marquette and Audrey Decker
item.dc:contributor: By Chris Marquette and Audrey Decker

item.title: Trump expands his lethal attacks on alleged drug traffickers
item.description: The U.S. military is now operating in the Pacific — and apparently targeting Colombian vessels.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trumps makes an announcement about fertility drugs in the Oval Office at the White House in Washington, Oct. 16, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Eric Bazail-Eimil
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Eric Bazail-Eimil

item.title: ‘Sean Dummy’: Musk and Duffy brawl over the future of NASA
item.description: It’s far from the first time the world’s richest man has lobbed broadsides at the administration.

media:content.media:title: Elon Musk attends a memorial for conservative activist Charlie Kirk on Sept. 21, 2025, at State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona.

item.dc:creator: By Gregory Svirnovskiy
item.dc:contributor: By Gregory Svirnovskiy

item.title: Trump affirms support for nuclear sub deal
item.description: Australia and the U.K. have feared for months that the U.S. would pull out of the AUKUS pact.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump greets Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the White House on Oct. 20, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould

item.title: Top nuclear weapons agency to furlough most staff amid shutdown
item.description: House Republicans pointed to the staff reductions as a national security consequence of the shutdown, pressing Senate Democrats to yield and vote to reopen the government.

media:content.media:title: House Armed Services Committee Chair Mike Rogers and top Republicans highlighted the national security impacts of the government shutdown as the blamed Democrats for the lapse. (J. Scott Applewhite/AP)

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien and Meredith Lee Hill
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien and Meredith Lee Hill

item.title: Top admiral steps down abruptly amid drug boat strikes
item.description: Adm. Alvin Holsey oversees Southern Command, where US military strikes against alleged Venezuelan drug traffickers at sea have ramped up.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth (center), shown at a ribbon-cutting ceremony on April 8, did not give a reason for the departure of Adm. Alvin Holsey (right), one of the few Black four-star officers in the military.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien and Joe Gould

item.title: Hegseth’s plane makes emergency stop in UK
item.description: All passengers, including Hegseth, were safe after the plane landed due to a crack in its windshield.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives to attend a meeting at the NATO Ministers of Defense Summit at the NATO headquarters in Brussels on October 15, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Aaron Pellish
item.dc:contributor: By Aaron Pellish

item.title: Hegseth warns of ‘costs on Russia’ in latest sign of shifting US stance
item.description: The Defense secretary spoke before a meeting of European defense leaders that he has skipped in the past.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth speaks with Britain's Defense Secretary John Healey during a meeting of the Ukraine Defense Contact Group at NATO headquarters in Brussels on Oct. 15, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Victor Jack
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Victor Jack

item.title: Major media outlets, including Hegseth’s former employer Fox News, decline to sign new Pentagon reporting rules
item.description: The former employer of the Secretary of Defense joined CNN, ABC and NBC in refusing to sign the agreement.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth speaks as President Donald Trump holds a cabinet meeting at the White House, Oct. 9, 2025, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Cheyanne M. Daniels
item.dc:contributor: By Cheyanne M. Daniels

item.title: Senate passes defense policy bill amid shutdown, troop pay standoff
item.description: The Senate and House must now negotiate a compromise defense bill over the coming months.

media:content.media:title: Senate Armed Services Chair Roger Wicker (R-Miss.) and ranking Democrat Jack Reed of Rhode Island reached a deal to pass their marquee defense bill that had stalled for weeks.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien

item.title: Senate votes to repeal Middle East war laws
item.description: The repeal of the Gulf and Iraq War authorizations is included in both the House and Senate defense bills, heightening its chances of passing.

media:content.media:title: Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Va. speaks to reporters at the Capitol, Oct. 1, 2025, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien
